headline.main: SUMMER LETTERS.; Journeyings to a Fashionoble watering-Place. Incidents and Observations on board a steamboat.

docs.lead_paragraph: I hardly know that my discursive scribbling will suit you; but when I confess what manner of man I am, you may, perhaps, pardon my old-fash ined notions, and make due allowance for the garrulous kinks of a confirmed " old fogy." To begin my likeness, I have already admitted that I am far advanced in life--too far, I fear, to be very unwilling to tell mv age;

byline.original: Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times

headline.main: AID TO NEW-ORLEANS.; Additional Contribution by Citizens of NewYork.

docs.lead_paragraph: The total receipts in this City in aid of the Yellow Fever sufferers ill New-Orleans, up to yesterday, amount to $35,618. The following correspondence explains itself: NEW-YORK, Friday, Aug. 26, 1853. To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: SIR: The Committee for the Relief of the Howard Association of New-Orleans acknowledge the following additional contributions since our last report, and would herewith express their thanks for the lively interest

headline.main: YOUNG AMERICA.; GEORGE N. SAUNDERS' FAREWELL FESTIVAL. Interesting Toasts, Speeches, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: GEORGE N. SAUNDERS, Esq., who has just been appointed by President PIERCE United States Consul at London, gave a dinner to a number of his political and personal friends at the Astor House last evening. It was a highly interesting and cordial festivity. Some twenty-five invited guests sat down, comprising not only distinguished Democrats, but prominent Whigs, from different sections of the Union.
docs.abstract: Farewell dinner at the Astor House

headline.main: PAPERS FROM STRAWBERRY HILL.; Sketches of American Statesmen. SECOND PAPER. Daniel Webster.
Have We a Scavenger among us?

docs.lead_paragraph: It is the privilege of great cities to he vexed with momentous questions. No sooner is a satisfactory solution discovered for one, than another usurps its place. From the beginning of the year to its end, we are constantly called on to determine if we have, or have not, such and such a thing among us.

headline.main: PHILADELPHIA.; The Weather--Business and Travel--Selling Dead Bodies--Political--Vegetarian Banquet--Supposed Murder--Marine Intelligence--Markets, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the way of news, there is but little to communicate which would interest New-York readers. The weather is cloudy to-day, with a breeze now and then from the northwest. The thermometer at noon stood at 83[degrees]. Our hotels are pretty well filled up with Southern and Western merchants, and a large number of visitors, on their way to the Crystal Palace.

byline.original: Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times

headline.main: BROOKLYN CITY.; BROOKLYN WATER-WORKS. Visit to the Long Island Ponds--Site for Reservoir, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: A party of some forty gentlemen met yesterday morning, by invitation of the Long Island Water Works Company, at the City Hall, Brooklyn, and Wiltiamsurg Ferry, where states were in readiness to convey them on a tour of inspection from the site of the proposed reservoir, west of Cypress Hills, to the ponds from which a supply is to be derived.

headline.main: The Mineralogical Department at the Crystal Palace.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: In the Herald of Wednesday, a writer, under the signature of " Common Sense," undertakes to explain the cause of the backwardness of the preparation of the cabinet of minerals in the Crystal Palace. This he ascribes to the fact that Professor S1LLIMAN is "lying dangerously ill " at New-Haven.
